column5: and the county town of Caithness
column6: at the head of Wick Bay
column7: near the middle of the E coast of the parish just described. It is the eastern terminus of the Sutherland and Caithness section (1874) of the Highland railway
column8: and by rail is 161¼ miles NNE of Inverness. By road it is 18½ miles S of Huna and John o' Groat's House
column9: and 14¾ NNE of Lybster. By sea it is about 50 miles S of Kirkwall
column10: and 110 NNW of Aberdeen. The town may be said to consist of three portions
column11: Wick proper to the N of Wick Water
column13: and Pulteneytown to the SE on the S side of Wick Water. The burgh was formerly confined within narrow limits
column14: but in 1883 the sheriff granted a petition praying for the inclusion within the boundary of both Louisburgh and the high ground on the opposite side of the river from Wick about the railway station. In the time of the Vikings
column15: from whom it received its name
column16: it seems to have been a resort of some importance
column17: and mention of it occurs in the Sagas as early as 1140
column18: when ` Earl Rognvald went over to Caithness and was entertained at Vik by a man named Harold; ' but its modern history may be said to date from 1589
column19: when Wick proper was constituted a royal burgh by charter of James VI. So little idea
column21: had the citizens as to their rights and privileges thus obtained
column22: that the burgh practically remained under superiors-first the Earls of Caithness and thereafter the families of Ulbster and Sutherland-like a mere burgh of barony till the Municipal Reform Act of 1833. There are no burgage lands
column23: and the Duke of Sutherland is still feudal superior. Wick itself consists of a narrow crooked street called High Street
column24: running in a general line N and S along the N bank of the river
column25: and with closes and lanes running off on both sides. It is poorly edificed. Lonisburgh
column26: which dates from the latter part of last century
column27: lies to the N and NW. Opening off High Street southward is the only wellbuilt street of the town
column29: which crosses the river by a fine stone bridge of three arches erected in 1874. This leads to Pulteneytown
column30: which is divided into Lower Pulteneytown
column31: situated on low ground adjoining the bank of the stream
column33: situated on the high ground overlooking the bay. The greater portion of both lies along streets regularly laid out at right angles
column34: Upper Pulteneytown having in addition a large but somewhat neglected central square. This suburb
column35: which is the seat of all the trade
column36: and contains more than half the whole population
column37: was laid out by the British Fisheries Society in 1808
column38: shortly before they commenced operations at the harbour
column39: and was designed to be a model fishing-town. Wick townhall
column41: is a somewhat dingy building with a sandstone front and a cupola-shaped belfry over the doorway. The county buildings
column42: erected in 1866 at a cost of £6000
column44: and contain a good court-room with retiring rooms and accommodation for the various county offices. The prison behind the town-house has been disused since 1882. The parish church
column45: at the W end of the town
column46: was erected in 1830 at a cost of £5000
column47: and is a poor Gothic building with a spire. It contains 1900 sittings. The preReformation parish church
column49: is supposed to have stood at Mount Halie
column50: near the E end of the town
column51: but a more recent structure-the predecessor of that removed to make way for the present building occupied a site close to the existing church. The only traces of it now remaining are the structures called the Sinclair Aisle and the Dinbar Tomb. At Pulteneytown there is a quoad sacra church erected in 1842
column52: and containing 550 sittings. The Free church in Bridge Street is a good building
column53: erected in 1862. Of two Free churches in Pulteneytown the one dates from the Disruption
column54: and has a spire added in 1862. The other Reformed Presbyterian till 1876-was built in 1839
column55: and contains 380 sittings. The United Presbyterian church in Pulteneytown
column56: - built in 1878-79 at a cost of £4000
column58: replaced an older church erected in 1815. The original Congregational church in Wick
column60: was replaced by the present building on a different site in 1882. It contains 500 sittings. The Evangelical Union church
column62: was erected in 1845. St John's Episcopal church
column67: and there are also a small Baptist church (1809)
column69: and St Joachim's Roman Catholic church in Pulteneytown
column71: and containing 250 sittings. The Temperance Hall
column73: has accommodation for about 1000 persons. Two of the bank offices are very good buildings
column74: and there is a fine hotel close to the bridge erected at the time of the opening of the railway. Besides the stone bridge at Bridge Street
column75: there is a wooden bridge farther down the river near the harbour. The old burying ground was round the church
column76: but owing to its crowded condition
column77: a new cemetery was formed in 1872 to the S of Pulteneytown. Under the burgh school board the Pulteneytown Academy
column78: North Wick and South Wick schools
column92:
8s. 6d.

The jurisdiction of the port of Wick extends from Bonar-Bridge round all the E
column94: and W coast as far as Rhu Stoer on the W coast of Sutherland
column95: and takes in also the island of Stroma in the Pentland Firth. It thus includes the harbours of Little Ferry
column101: besides numerous creeks. Except as regards fishing-boats
column102: the shipping trade is mostly confined to Wick. In 1850 the number of vessels belonging to the port was 54
column103: with an aggregate tonnage of 3445; in 1875 there were 65 sailing vessels
column106: with a tonnage of 108; and in 1884 there were 56 sailing vessels
column107: with an aggregate tonnage of 5085. The following table shows the tonnage of vessels that entered from and to foreign and colonial ports and coastwise with cargoes and ballast

column5: and country produce generally are also sent away. The imports are principally coal
column7: and goods suited for a general country trade. There is regular steam communication with Aberdeen and Granton twice a week in summer and once in winter
column8:
and with Kirkwall and Lerwick once a week.

The commerce of early times seems to have found accommodation in the mouth of the river
column9: and at small jetties on the N side; and no attempt to form a regular harbour was made till 1810
column10: when the first one was constructed
column12: and partly with money furnished by the British Fisheries Society
column13: originally founded in 1786 for the purpose of developing the fisheries round the British coasts. The works then executed cost £14
column14: 000; but as they proved inadequate for their purpose
column15: improvements were carried out between 1825 and 1831 at a cost of £40
column17: and the works brought into the state in which they remained down to 1882. From the increased size of vessels and boats employed in connection with the fishing
column21: and in 1844 the Fisheries Society obtained an Act of Parliament empowering them to enlarge it. Nothing was
column24: and in consequence of the insufficient nature of the accommodation
column25: and the harbour's being a tidal one
column26: and having its mouth so placed to shelter it from the sea that boats entering 189 had to broach broadside to the sea before running in
column27: great loss of life occurred in 1845
column28: and again in 1848. In 1857 a fresh Act was obtained
column29: but as the scheme proposed under it required the sanction of the Admiralty
column30: and that body wished for the formation of a harbour of refuge which the Society could not afford to carry out
column32: when it was agreed that a modified harbour of refuge should be formed. This was to be accomplished by the construction of a breakwater running out from the S shore of the bay 430 yards to the SE of the old works
column33: and extending 1450 feet outward at right angles to the shore
column35: and sheltering an area of about 25 acres
column36: of which more than 20 had a depth of over 2 fathoms at low water. The force of the waves in the bay seems
column41: the principle of construction was not wholly wrong; and year after year portions of the great pier were thrown down. At last
column48: in terrific gales during the years 1871 and 1872-when the force of the waves was such as to break iron bars measuring 8 by 3 inches-the whole structure was completely ruined
column49: except a fragment of the shore end
column51: from which time till 1880 the storms of each winter swept away portion after portion of what remained. In 1879 a fresh Act was obtained by the Fisheries Society
column52: empowering them to hand over the whole works to a body of trustees elected by public bodies in the town
column53: while all sums against the harbour for repayment of the sums expended on it by the Society were abandoned. The old works were injured by the storms of 1880; and the trustees obtained from the Treasury
column55: and ultimately in 1882 a suspension of the present repayment of the £60
column56: 000 due to the Public Works Loan Commissioners; and under a provisional order obtained in 1883
column57: they have proceeded with new works which are estimated to cost £90
column60: 000 is to be obtained on loan from the Public Works Commissioners. These operations contemplate the lengthening of the south quay 300 feet
column61: the erection of a new north quay outside the present one
column62: so as to enlarge the existing harbour by 2½ acres
column63: and the deepening of the whole area by 8 feet
column64:
the extreme depth of the entrance at low water being thus about 17 feet.

The great industry of Wick is fishing
column65: particularly herring fishing. Prior to 1768 the only herring caught were by hand lines for bait; but then
column66: under the encouragement of a parliamentary bounty
column67: boats were fitted out for systematic prosecution of the trade. In that year
column74: 000 barrels; and ever since the formation of the harbour it has been frequented by large numbers of boats from all quarters. During the season
column76: this gives the place a somewhat ` ancient and fish-like smell
column77: ' and herring and herring barrels are everywhere to be found along the shore
column78: sometimes occupying considerable spaces along the sides of the streets in the portion of the town nearest the harbour. The fishermen come from all parts of Scotland
column79: the greater number being ` hired men ' from the Western Highlands and Islands. The fishery district of Wick extends from Whale Goe or Whaligoe
column80: 7 miles N by W of the town of Wick
column81: round the rest of the Moray Firth and N and W coasts as far as Cape Wrath. It embraces the fishing towns and villages of Whaligoe
column116: and Smoo. Half of the boats and men employed
column117: and about two-thirds of the first-class boats
column118: belong to Wick itself and the neighbouring places. Belonging to the district there were
column123: employing 2642 fisher n en and boys and 3776 other persons. The boats were valued at £51
column127: and the lines as 458. The number of boats fishing within the district
column128: most of them from Wick harbour and the neighbouring Broadhaven
column130: and from this time it gradually increased till 1831 when it was 1021
column132: increased in 1857 to 1100 and in 1862 to 1122
column134: owing to the insufficient harbour accommodation
column135: fallen off very largely. The number in 1883 was 518
column138: the best average fishing per boat ever made. There were employed in connection with these boats 3367 fisher men and boys and 2186 other persons
column139: and the total number of barrels cured was 155
column142: 842 were exported to the Continent. A bank within ten miles of Wick
column145: the town being in winter and spring one of the great centres of this industry. The number of cod
column151: were captured. Minor industries are the manufacture of ropes
column153: and herring nets; and there is a large steam sawmill in Wick
column154:
and a distillery and brewery in Pulteneytown.

The burgh is governed by a provost
column158: and 9 councillors; and under the General Police and Improvement Act of 1862
column160: the councillors are also police commissioners
column161: but the police force is united with that of the county. The British Fisheries Society are superiors of Pulteneytown
column162: but there are 12 improvement commissioners who exercise local power
column165: form the Local Authority. There is a separate police force of 3 men (one to every 1691 or the population)
column166: under a superintendent with a salary of £50 a year. Gas is supplied by a private company constituted in 1846. Pulteneytown is supplied with water from Loch Hempriggs
column167: and a supply was introduced into the other districts in 1882 from Loch of Yarehouse at a cost of £6000. The town has a head post office
column172: branch offices of the Bank of Scotland
column176: and Town and County Banks. There is also a branch of the National Security Savings' Bank
column178: and several good hotels. The newspapers are the Liberal John o' Groat Journal (1836)
column181: published on Wednesday evening. Among the miscellaneous institutions may be noticed a custom-house
column182: a station of the Naval Reserve
column183: with buildings erected in 1876 on the South Head
column189: a branch of the Shipwrecked Mariners' Society
column190: and the usual benevolent and philanthropic associations. Sheriff ordinary and commissary courts for the county are held every Tuesday and Friday during session
column191: and small debt courts for the parishes of Wick
column194: and Canisbay every Tuesday during session. Down till 1828 these courts were held at Thurso. (See Thurso.) Quarter sessions are held at both Wick and Thurso
column195: and justice of peace small debt courts on the first and third Mondays of each month. There is a weekly market on Friday
column196: and there are fairs on the second last Tuesday of July
column199: and on the last Friday of every other month. There is a coach to Castletown and Thurso
column200:
and another to Lybster and Dunbeath every day.

The parliamentary burgh
column210: and Kirkwall in returning a member to parliament. Parliamentary constituency (1885) 941; municipal 448. Valuation
column214: including £478 for the railway; parliamentary burgh (1875) £21
column223: of whom 3810 were males and 4243 were females. Houses (1881) 1258 inhabited
column225: and 10 being built. Of the whole population 5253 were in Pulteneytown
column227: and 940 in Louisburgh; and of the inhabited houses 791 were in Pulteneytown
